I should clarify that I did not expect to get a definitive answer 
from any=
one when I asked the question.  As Dr. Jones stated up front, 
no one knows=
 the full answer, and that's absolutely true.  What I was 
more interested =
in was how the leaders in these areas of biology 
think about this issue, w=
hich I see as one of the most profound 
puzzles at the core of evolution, w=
hether natural or artificial.  
Thus, it is intriguing to learn the depth o=
f insight that they can 
draw from their respective realms of expertise.

S=
o when I express disappointment over the answers, it is not because 
they f=
ailed to solve the entire problem.  Rather, it is that the 
answers were ma=
inly superficial and perhaps even touching on the 
obvious (of course to a =
GECCO audience what is obvious is quite 
different than to a normal audienc=
e).  It left me feeling that, at 
least within their spheres of research, t=
he puzzles of complexity are 
seen more as peripheral curiosities than para=
digm-defining problems.  
While it is certainly possible that they have dee=
per insights than 
those they offered, it seems a bit strange that they wou=
ld fail to 
share them at a debate headlined as "evolution and complexity" =
in 
front of an audience of Ph.D. scientists.  So it's not unreasonable 
to=
 conclude they don't have a lot to say on the subject that is 
particularly=
 groundbreaking.

If that is true, my view is that it is somewhat unfortuna=
te for 
biology.  So while their answers perhaps reflect the best the field=
 
has to offer (as Thomas speculates may be the case), the field in 
that c=
ase must bear the burden of ignoring such important issues.  By 
the way, I=
 know that some biologists such as Raff and Meinhardt probe 
these issues m=
uch deeper than this panel did, so I would not naively 
endict the entire f=
ield.  But the mainstream seems a bit off the 
track.  

What's really inte=
resting about all this, from a GECCO point of view, 
is that it may be that=
 evolutionary computation, rather than biology, 
is where some of the most =
powerful secrets of evolution are beginning 
to fall out.   Who would have =
thought?  

Most people at GECCO who I spoke to after the debate echoed the=
 
sentiment that they hadn't really learned much, and in fact, had 
heard d=
eeper insights on evolution and complexity during GDS-track 
(Generative an=
d Developmental Systems, a track at GECCO) paper talks 
than during the key=
note event.

ken
